docs.lead_paragraph: SLOW.--The Quarantine Commissioners still talk over the steam tug by which the Health Officer is to board vessels on their arrival from sea, but they don't get the tug yet, and probably won't. Tugs enough are to be had, but to be tied by Quarantine laws, as they would have to be, is so annoying that an exorbitant demand is asked for the purpose.

docs.lead_paragraph: Our special Kansas correspondent, in a letter dated Lecompton, June 30, states that Governor WALKER had just returned from Paoli, where he had been to attend the land sales. The Governor, the Secretary, and Governor BIGLER, of Pennsylvania, made speeches at Paoli to the people with the most satisfactory result.

docs.lead_paragraph: TAKING OUT AN EYE TO MEND IT.--The Leipgic Journal of Literature, Science and Art, publishes an account of the wonderful discoveries of Dr. GEARFF, in the diseases of the eye, and the wonderful cures he performs. He has found the ball of the eye to be transpa?ent, and, by a curious instrument, examines minutely the interior, takes it out, and performs any necessary surgical operation,

headline.main: THE PRIZE RING.; The Fight for [Pounds]400 and the Championship of England between Tom Sayers and the Tipton Slasher.

docs.lead_paragraph: Bell's Life in London of June 21 contains a full account of the late pugilistic encounter between Tom Sayers and the Tipton Slasher, for (Pound)400 and the Championship of England.
docs.snippet: Bell's Life in London of June 21 contains a full account of the late pugilistic encounter between Tom Sayers and the Tipton Slasher, for (Pound)400 and the Championship of England.

headline.main: Dedging Quarantire--Carrying Yellow Fever to New-Jersey.
NEW-JERSEY.; Fatal Affair in Hoboken--A. Young Cuban Shoots the Brother of his Teacher.

docs.lead_paragraph: A sad affair occurred in Hoboken, N. J., on Wednesday night which has caused a good deal of excitement in that locality. At 11 o'clock Wednesday night as Mr. OSCAR DE GRAND-VAL was leaving the house No. 15 Washington-terrace, where he had been spend. ing the evening, he was attacked by a young Caban named FREDERICO CUEVA, who struck him several times with a cane.

docs.lead_paragraph: In reference to the report of the massacre of Col. SUMMER'S party by the Indians, the Washington Union of yesterday contains the following: "No intelligence confirmatory of the above has been received at the War Department, and no confidence is placed in the report. It is hardly possible that so large a body of United States troops could be taken by surprise and completely annihilated, especially troops well acquainted with the Indian made of fighting."

docs.lead_paragraph: QUARANTINED.--The following vessels were yesterday sent from the upper to the lower Quarantine for anchorage: Brig St. Michael, from St. Domingo City; she lost a man coming home. Brig Peruvian, from Trinidad, which lost two mates in port, and two men on the passage.

headline.main: FUNERAL OF GOVERNOR MARCY.; FUNERAL OF GOVERNOR MARCY. Splendid Civic and Military Displ Presidents Van Buren and Pierce Present. Presidents Van Buren and Pierce Present. governors Bouck, Fish, Hunt and Seymour, and Senators Seward and King, and Major-General Wool, Pall-Bearers. Splendid Civic and Military Display.

docs.lead_paragraph: There is a large audience gathered in Albany to-day, to pay tribute and give fitting burial to the last remains of WILLIAM LEARNED MARCY--a more numerous and apparently sincere array of mourners than I have ever before met, save when the body of HENRY CLAY was on its last pilgrimage to Ashland.

docs.lead_paragraph: VAN BRUNT.--In this City, on Tuesday evening, July 7, at the residence of her son-in-law. J. Carhart, Mrs BEISKY VAN BRUNT, aged 68 years. Her remains were taken to Troy, N.Y., for interment. COBNELL-In this City, on Monday, July 6, KYCER C. COBNELL, at No 319 3d st., aged 41 years. The remains were interred in the Cemetery of the Evergreens.
